@Sam Mingolelli : The reason we moved it to a dedicated github org was that we could never bring in maintainers without them having access to other private stuff in the org. So we moved it about a week ago so that wouldn't be an issue.

It is listed on the page that lists are OS stuff: http://stackexchange.github.io/

@Mike: One of the major pieces of Bosun is the time series database, and we use OpenTSDB for that. Beyond that, nothing else fit our needs (and my speculation is that what is out there also doesn't fit the needs of many other orgs as well).

So .. give me a quick elevator brief on what is possible with bosun that isn't possible with [other stuff].

Like this: our devops team uses logstash / kibana for the Saas we run. The internal support team uses nothing, at this point, but we're looking at our options: anything other than logstash/kibana needs to be really, really good.
That last post, by me, comes across as rude, and I'm sorry.  If you could sprinkle that with a few 'please' and 'thank you'  and a little humility, that would be great.

@Brian: I honestly struggle to boil it down since there are lot of things. But the main result is "Far less alert noise", but it has more implications than that. It has less alert noise because:
 
- Instead of just using recent values, the full time series is available to alert on

- There is an expression language that lets you define and tune accurate alert conditions based on that time series data (And there is no 1:1 mapping here, you can use multiple metrics, objects etc)

- The templating language lets you create more informative notifications

 - The interface lets you test how alerts would have behaved against history. This is big, this means the alert tuning and development cycle goes from days/weeks to minutes.

 - scollector gets you a lot of high resolution monitoring for windows and linux out of the box

Maybe the examples on bosun.org might give a hint of this.

That help?

I think they made something to fit their specific needs that may also benefit others - and decided to make it available to the public, Mike. 

From that perspective, it isn't a matter of necessity of yet another monitoring/alert framework - they're offering one more option for those in need of one.

That's said, go team Bosun!

"Maybe the examples on bosun.org might give a hint of this.  That help?"

If not, I'm not interested.
